chuan bei
bei mu

Biological: Fritillaria cirrhosa D. Don (chuan bei mu)
Fritillaria unibracteata Hsiao et K. C. Hsiao (chuan bei mu)
Fritillaria verticillata Willd. var. Fritillaria thunbergii Bak. (zhe bei mu)
Other: jian bei mu 尖貝母 (chuan bei mu)
xiang bei 象貝 (zhe bei mu)
da bei mu 大貝母 (zhe bei mu)

Geography: China: chuan bei mu: Sichuan, Yunnan, Xizang
China: zhe bei mu: Zhejiang, Jiangsu, Anhui, Hunan
Properties: chuan bei mu: mildly cold, sweet, bitter
Maladies Treated: hot cough due to yinxu with thick phlegm
chronic cough with injured yin (yin xu), dry cough without phlegm (chuan bei mu)
cough with yellow phlegm (zhe bei mu)
external pathogenic wind with phlegm stagnation causing cough, scrofula, boils (zhe bei mu)
Medical Function: Clears lung heat and rids of phlegm
Chuan bei mu: mildly cold and good at moisturizing, suitable for cough due to lung dryness and yin deficiency, dry cough without phlegm
Zhe bei mu: bitter and colder than chuan bei mu; strong purging function to clear lung heat, dissolve stagnant phlegm, stop coughing, suitable for treating cough with yellow phlegm, scrofula, boils
Suppress cough and expels phlegm
Small amounts of saponins from bei mu increase blood pressure of dogs, cats, and rabbits; large amounts lower their blood pressure (animal experiment)
Injection of 7.5 ml/kg peimine into rabbits increased their blood sugar and maintained elevation for more than 2 hours (animal experiment)
Antibiotic effect
Dosage: For decoction: 3 to 10 g. As powder form (mixed in water): 1 to 2 g.
Samples of Formulae: dang gui bei mu ku shen wan 當歸貝母苦參丸, jie geng bai san 桔梗白散, yang fei tang 養肺湯
Contraindications: Not to be used by patients with pi xu (spleen deficiency) type cold with wet phlegm and cold cough. Also not to use she dan chuan bei mo (snake bile chuan bei powder), chen pi chuan bei mo (tangerine peel chuan bei powder), chuan bei mu powder, and fu fang she dan chuan bei mo. Raw bei mu is toxic and must not be used internally.

Name: zi su ye
紫蘇葉
Biological: P. frutescens (L.) Britt. var. typica Makino

Maladies Treated: influenza with fever, unable to sweat, stuffy nose, headache, tightness in chest, vomiting
food poisoning from eating fish or shellfish causing abdominal pain, vomiting and diarrhea
Medical Function: antipyretic, expands skin blood vessels, stimulate sweat glands
inhibits germs and fungi
promotes secretion of digestive juices and enhances the movements of stomach and intestines
oleanolic acid and ursolic acid were both reported to have anti-inflammatory activity [1]
Dosage: For decoction: 5 to 10 g. Boil briefly. Food poisoning from fish or crab: use single item of zi su leaf up to 30 g. External use: smash and apply to affected areas or wash with decoction.
Samples of Formulae: Wind cold type of flu: use xing su san (Apricot Kernel and Perilla Leaf Powder)
Contraindications: Not to use in cases of febrile diseases, qixu (qi deficient) or weak exterior. According to the Whole Nation of Japan Farmers' Federation, five herbs (chen pi, su ye, da zao, jie shi, shan zhu yu) sold in the market have been found to contain farm chemical residues, especially high residue in chen pi. Although there is suspicion of conflict of interest, credibility is high, therefore it is advised to thoroughly soak the herb in water and wash well before use. Symptoms of weak exterior (biao xu syndrome): instant sweating, dislike draft, pale complexion, pale tongue with white fur, floating and weak, soft pulse, catching cold easily.
Research: According to research, oleanolic acid and ursolic acid have been reported to have anti-inflammatory activity in studies [1].
Notes: zi su is a farm grown plant. It is widely cultivated throughout China. The wild varieties exist in specific provinces listed under Geography.
References: [1] Nadinic, E.; Gorzalczany, S.; Rojo, A.; Baren, C. V.; Fototerapia 1999, 70, 166.

Name: yan hu suo
延胡索
Biological: Corydalis bulbosa D.C. var. typica, Regl.
Croydalis turtschaninovii Bess.f.yanhusuo Y.H.Chou et C.C. Hsu (Eastern China)
Croydalis ambigua Cham. et Schlectt. var. amurensis Maxim.(Eastern China)

Maladies Treated: painful injuries due to blood stasis after impact trauma
Medical Function: Promotes blood circulation, moves Qi, and alleviates pain.
Analgesic, sedative, hypnotic properties.
Improves blood circulation in coronary arteries and heart muscles.
Anti-ulcer effect.
Anti-spasmodic effect.
Dosage: 5 to 10 g in decoction. 1.5 to 3 g, taken as powder.
Contraindications: Not to use in cases of heat in blood, qi deficiency, or those with early arrival of menses or during pregnancy. Long term usage can be toxic to the heart and kidneys. Do not use with chlorpromazine hydrochloride—both possess CNS sedative effects, using together may cause tremor and numbness. Do not use with CNS stimulants like caffeine and phenylalanine, as d1-tetrahydropalmatine possesses sedative effects and can mitigate stimulant effects. Do not use with monoamine oxidase inhibitors like Pargylini Hydrochloridam, because the hypotensive effect of palmatine can be mitigated. Do not use with strychnine or ma qian zi (Strychnos nux-vomica seed) because it can increase their toxicity.
Research: In a study where monkeys were given internally by feeding dI-tetrahydropalmatine at dosage 85 mg/kg or 110 mg/kg or under skin injection at 80mg/kg, there was no evident toxicity reaction. Monkeys only exhibited sedation and hypnotic conditions. After two weeks of continuous application, slight swelling and fuzziness in heart and kidney tissues were observed under pathological examination.
Chemical Ingredients: Contains varieties of alkaloids totaling 0.59% to 0.74% of the herb.

Main chemical ingredients include: d-Corydaline, d1-Tetrahydropalmatine, Protopine, I-Tetrahydrocoptisine, dl-tetrahydrocoptisine, I-Tetrahydrocolumbamine, d-Corybulbine, d-Glaucine, a-Allo-Oryptopine, β-Homochelidonine, Coptisine, Dehydrocorydaline, Corydalmine, Dehydrocorydalmine, Columbamine, d-Glaucine.

Name: xiao long ji
Botanical: Strobilanthes affinis (Griff.) Terash. ex J. R. I. Wood et J. R. Benett
Other: xing yi ding tou ma lan 興義頂頭馬藍
ding tou ma lan 頂頭馬藍

Geography: Yunnan, Guizhou, Guangxi, Hunan, Guangdong, Sichuan provinces of China
Medical Function: Rid of infection; clears heat, resolves toxins, cools blood. Used for conditions such as influenza, meningitis, encephalitis, pneumonia, erysipelas, typhus, confusion and spitting blood.
Inhibiting effect on HBsAg and HBeAg
Dosage: Oral: make into decoction 10~15 g; fresh herb: 30~60 g, or make into juice or grind into powder. External application: use appropriate amount. Decoction for washing affected areas or fresh herb ground into paste for topical application.
Contraindications: Over use can damage digestion. This herb is not suitable for those with pixu (spleen deficient), xue xu (blood deficient), qixu (qi deficient).

Name: dang gui
dang qui
Biological: Angelica polymorpha Maxim. var sinensis Olive
Ligusticum acutilobum, S. et Z. (ma wei dang gui 馬尾當歸)
Ligusticum ibukiene, Yabe. (chan tou dang gui 饞 頭當歸)
Ligusticum japonium, Max. (cao dang gui 草 當歸)
Common: Chinese angelica root (commonly written as: tong kwai, dong quai)

Maladies Treated: dang gui wei (tail of dang gui root) treats blood stasis, clots, traumatic Injuries

Stroke due to poor blood circulation
Clinical studies involved a total of 40 patients. In one method, 30 patients received 25% Dang Gui injection intravenously, 200–300 ml per day, once daily for 15 or 30 days. Another 10 patients received 80–160 ml per day for 10–20 days. Results showed 12 patients were basically healed, 13 greatly improved, 11 improved, and 4 showed no effect. In another trial, 50 patients were treated with 200 ml per day of 25% Dang Gui injection intravenously for 20 days. Results were: 13 obviously effective, 9 got better, and 3 ineffective. The overall circulation improvement rate was 94%.
Hardening of arteries in the brain
Chronic pulmonary thrombosis and pulmonary hypertension

Headache
50 patients received 20% Dang Gui solution injected into specific acupoints (Shu Xue) on the back. Within 30 minutes, plasma DBH levels were significantly reduced. Of these, 27 patients had vasomotor dysfunction and 23 had neuropathy.
Bleeding of the upper digestive tract

Psoriasis
100 patients were treated with daily injections of 2% Dang Gui solution combined with 2% Procaine (4 ml total) for 30 days. Acupoint selection included He Gu, Qu Chi, Fei Shu, Gan Shu, Wei Shu, Zhang Men, Tian Xu, Zhu San Li, and San Yin Jiao. Results showed 84 patients healed, 9 showed obvious improvement, and 7 improved. A follow-up conducted 6 months to 4 years later recorded 5 cases of relapse.

Bronchial asthma
A preparation called Dang Gui Jin You Wan was made from Dang Gui essential oil containing ligustilide (藁本內酯). In a group of 57 patients, children under 12 received 100 mg and adults received 150 mg, three times a day for 7 days. Results showed a 74.5% obvious effectiveness rate and a total effectiveness rate of 90.2%. No obvious side effects were observed. Ineffective cases involved patients with lung sac swelling or underlying cardiopulmonary diseases. Generally, asthma symptoms subsided within 2–3 hours, and wheezing reduced within 8–24 hours. Its effect was described as slow and stable, improving circulation and airflow, suitable for mild to severe asthma episodes.
Gastric inflammation, duodenal and gastric ulcers
Medical Function: Tonic for blood and for regulating the menses
lubricates bowels to correct constipation
reduces swelling, expels pus, relieves pain
effects on uterus: experiments showed that it can have inhibiting and stimulating effects on animal uterine tissue outside the body
lowers blood lipids, anti platelet coagulation, promotes production of red blood cells
dilates coronary arteries of guinea pigs, improving circulation volume
protects rats from arrhythmia in lab experiments
anti oxidation and removal of free radicals
anti radiation injury effect
improves immune system
anti-cancer effect: five polysaccharides from ming xian dang gui inhibited EC, Hep, S180, Lewis B16 tumors in lab rats up to 39%, minimal side effects, safe for long term use
anti inflammatory and analgesic properties
protects digestive system and liver
alone does not produce estrogen-like responses in endometrial thickness or in vaginal maturation, no more effective than placebo for menopausal symptoms relief
extract of huang qi (Astragalus) and dang gui (3:1 ratio) shows suppression of breast cancer cells
Dosage: 10 to 15 g per day in decoction. Avoid prolonged cooking to preserve oils and medicinal effectiveness.
Samples of Formulae:
Formulae include ba zhen tang 八珍湯, dang gui jian zhong tang 當歸健中湯, dang gui long hui wan 當歸龍薈丸, gui pi tang 歸脾湯, jiao ai tang 膠艾湯, Li Dong Yuan qing feng san 李東垣清風散, tuo hua jian 脫花煎, sheng hua tang 生化湯 (composition: dang gui, chuan xiong, tao ren, he jiang (dark baked ginger), zhi gan cao; treats postpartum failure to expel clotted blood with lower abdominal pain), shi quan da bu tang 十全大補湯, si wu tang 四物湯, formulae for idiopathic thrombocytopenia purpura (ITP). 
 Sheng Hua Tang (Decoction for Generating Transformation), recorded in Fu’s Gynecology (《傅氏女科》), is used to treat postpartum conditions where lochia (uterine discharge) fails to be expelled, resulting in retained blood clots and lower abdominal pain. The formula consists of Dang Gui (Angelica sinensis), Chuan Xiong (Ligusticum chuanxiong), Tao Ren (peach kernel), He Jiang (dark baked ginger), and Zhi Gan Cao (honey-fried licorice root). This classical prescription promotes blood circulation, dispels blood stasis, warms the meridians, and alleviates pain, making it especially effective in addressing abdominal discomfort and stagnation following childbirth.
Contraindications: Not advised in cases of dampness with fullness, flatulence or chronic diarrhea. Not recommended for prolonged use or large dosages by some women after menopause or some men. Overcooking decreases effectiveness due to loss of volatile oils.
Research: Anti-cancer research showed five polysaccharides of ming xian dang gui inhibited EC, Hep, S180, Lewis B16 implanted tumors in rats by up to 39%. Few side effects noted, suitable for long term use. Australian research noted frequent ingestion of ginseng and dang gui accelerates multiplication of breast cancer cells. Dang gui alone showed no estrogen-like response on endometrial thickness or vaginal maturation, not better than placebo in relieving menopausal symptoms. Huang qi (Astragalus) and dang gui extract at a 3:1 ratio showed breast cancer cell suppression.
Notes:
Sudden deafness, bronchial asthma, stomach and duodenal ulcers, limb paralysis in toddlers, and numerous other ailments have been listed as treatable by dang gui. Some methods of treatments remain undocumented in the original text (marked as Methods to be loaded). Detailed clinical study results showed efficacy in conditions such as stroke, headaches, psoriasis and asthma using intravenous and shu xue injection methods. Dang gui jin you wan (preparation using essential oil component ligustilide) reported effective against asthma with minimal side effects. 
 DBH (Dopamine β-Hydroxylase): Dopamine β-hydroxylase (DBH) is an enzyme involved in the conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine. Elevated serum levels of DBH have been reported in migraine patients during acute attacks. Moreover, significantly increased DBH activity has also been observed during headache-free intervals, which may predispose individuals to the onset of migraine episodes. 
 Shu Xue (腧穴): In traditional Chinese medicine, xue refers to “cave,” “depression,” or “point.” All acupuncture points along the body’s meridians (channels) are known as xue. Among these, the points that reflect the function of internal organs are specifically called shu points, or shu xue. These are primarily located along the bladder meridian and are key locations for diagnosis and treatment in acupuncture and moxibustion.
Chemical Ingredients: Essential oils: b-pinene, camphene, P-cymene, b-phellandrene, myrcene, b-ocimene-X, allo-ocimene, 6-n-butyl-cycloheptadiene-1,4, 2-methyl-dodecane-5-one, acetophenone, b-bisabolene, isoacroraene, acoradiene, chamigrene, a-cedrene, n-butyl-tetrahydrophthalide, n-butyl-phthalide, n-butylidene-phthalide, ligustilide, d-2,4-dihydrophthalic anhydride, dodecanol, bergapten

Phenolic oil: P-methyl-benzolcohol, 5-methoxyl-2,3-dicresol, phenol, O-cresol, P-cresol, guaiacol, 2,3-dicresol, P-ethyl phenol, O-ethyl phenol, 4-ethyl resorcinol, 2,4-dihydroacetophenone, carvacrol, isoeugenol, vanillin
Oils with Acid Characteristics: phthalic anhydride, azelaic acid, sebacic acid, anisic acid, myristic acid, camphoric acid, various dimethyl esters
Organic acids: ferulic acid, succinic acid, nicotinic acid, vanillic acid, n-tetracosanoic acid, palmitic acid
Inorganic elements: 20 types, 16 essential for humans including calcium, zinc, phosphorous, selenium
Other: stigmasterol, sitosterol, stigmaterol-d-glucoside, tetradecanol-1, scopletin, 6-methoxyl-7-hydroxycoumarin, angelicide, brefelclin A, phytoestrogens
